author: Special Correspondent
text:
Koolamedu village has about 30 bulls, which regularly participate in the jallikattu in the village and also in other parts of the State.

M. Sasikumar (38) owned three bulls which have been regularly participating in this event. His father and grand father too possessed jallikattu bulls. He started giving nutritious diet to the bulls right from November. The diet included kollu (horse gram) pottu, raw paddy, cotton seeds, uludhu (dhal) puttu and eggs of desi chicken.

“I spend about Rs. 250 to Rs. 300 a day for feeding each bull,” Mr. Sasikumar says.

Training in swimming is a major exercise for the bulls. Since the entire Attur union has been reeling under severe drought condition and the lake has remained dry, training is being given in water tubs, he says.

His bulls have taken part in jallikattu in all the southern districts, he says.

Koolamedu is witnessing a stream of visitors from the neighbouring villages to see the bulls undergoing training.

The prize money ranging up to Rs. 1 lakh has been announced for the bull tamers at the Koolamedu jallikattu. Even, some enthusiasts came forward to present piece of lands for the successful tamers.
title: Training the bulls
